t: Matthew 20
The Parable of the Workers in the Vineyard
“For*rp the*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r a*r landowner*r who*r went*r out*r early*r in*r the*r morning*r to*r hire*r workers*r for*r his*r vineyard.*r
He*r agreed*r to*r pay*r them*r a*r denarius*r for*r the*r day*r and*r sent*r them*r into*r his*r vineyard.*r
“About*rp nine*r in*r the*r morning*r he*r went*r out*r and*r saw*r others*r standing*r in*r the*r marketplace*r doing*r nothing.*r
He*r told*r them,*r ‘You*r also*r go*r and*r work*r in*r my*r vineyard,*r and*r I*r will*r pay*r you*r whatever*r is*r right.’*r
So*r they*r went.*r “He*rp went*r out*r again*r about*r noon*r and*r about*r three*r in*r the*r afternoon*r and*r did*r the*r same*r thing.*r

About*r five*r in*r the*r afternoon*r he*r went*r out*r and*r found*r still*r others*r standing*r around.*r He*r asked*r them,*r ‘Why*r have*r you*r been*r standing*r here*r all*r day*r long*r doing*r nothing?’*r
“ ‘Because*rp no*r one*r has*r hired*r us,’*r they*r answered.*r “He*rp said*r to*r them,*r ‘You*r also*r go*r and*r work*r in*r my*r vineyard.’*r

“When*rp evening*r came,*r the*r owner*r of*r the*r vineyard*r said*r to*r his*r foreman,*r ‘Call*r the*r workers*r and*r pay*r them*r their*r wages,*r beginning*r with*r the*r last*r ones*r hired*r and*r going*r on*r to*r the*r first.’*r
“The*rp workers*r who*r were*r hired*r about*r five*r in*r the*r afternoon*r came*r and*r each*r received*r a*r denarius.*r
So*r when*r those*r came*r who*r were*r hired*r first,*r they*r expected*r to*r receive*r more.*r But*r each*r one*r of*r them*r also*r received*r a*r denarius.*r
When*r they*r received*r it,*r they*r began*r to*r grumble*r against*r the*r landowner.*r

‘These*r who*r were*r hired*r last*r worked*r only*r one*r hour,’*r they*r said,*r ‘and*r you*r have*r made*r them*r equal*r to*r us*r who*r have*r borne*r the*r burden*r of*r the*r work*r and*r the*r heat*r of*r the*r day.’*r
“But*rp he*r answered*r one*r of*r them,*r ‘I*r am*r not*r being*r unfair*r to*r you,*r friend.*r Didn’t*r you*r agree*r to*r work*r for*r a*r denarius?*r
Take*r your*r pay*r and*r go.*r I*r want*r to*r give*r the*r one*r who*r was*r hired*r last*r the*r same*r as*r I*r gave*r you.*r
Don’t*r I*r have*r the*r right*r to*r do*r what*r I*r want*r with*r my*r own*r money?*r Or*r are*r you*r envious*r because*r I*r am*r generous?’*r
“So*rp the*r last*r will*r be*r first,*r and*r the*r first*r will*r be*r last.”*r
Jesus Predicts His Death a Third Time
Now*p Jesus was going up to Jerusalem. On the way, he took the Twelve aside and said to them,

“We*r are*r going*r up*r to*r Jerusalem,*r and*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r will*r be*r delivered*r over*r to*r the*r chief*r priests*r and*r the*r teachers*r of*r the*r law.*r They*r will*r condemn*r him*r to*r death*r
and*r will*r hand*r him*r over*r to*r the*r Gentiles*r to*r be*r mocked*r and*r flogged*r and*r crucified.*r On*r the*r third*r day*r he*r will*r be*r raised*r to*r life!”*r
A Mother’s Request
Then*p the mother of Zebedee’s sons came to Jesus with her sons and, kneeling down, asked a favor of him.
“What*rp is*r it*r you*r want?”*r he asked. She*p said, “Grant that one of these two sons of mine may sit at your right and the other at your left in your kingdom.”
“You*rp don’t*r know*r what*r you*r are*r asking,”*r Jesus said to them. “Can*r you*r drink*r the*r cup*r I*r am*r going*r to*r drink?”*r “We*p can,” they answered.

Jesus*p said to them, “You*r will*r indeed*r drink*r from*r my*r cup,*r but*r to*r sit*r at*r my*r right*r or*r left*r is*r not*r for*r me*r to*r grant.*r These*r places*r belong*r to*r those*r for*r whom*r they*r have*r been*r prepared*r by*r my*r Father.”*r
When*p the ten heard about this, they were indignant with the two brothers.
Jesus called them together and said, “You*r know*r that*r the*r rulers*r of*r the*r Gentiles*r lord*r it*r over*r them,*r and*r their*r high*r officials*r exercise*r authority*r over*r them.*r
Not*r so*r with*r you.*r Instead,*r whoever*r wants*r to*r become*r great*r among*r you*r must*r be*r your*r servant,*r
and*r whoever*r wants*r to*r be*r first*r must*r be*r your*r slave—*r
just*r as*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r did*r not*r come*r to*r be*r served,*r but*r to*r serve,*r and*r to*r give*r his*r life*r as*r a*r ransom*r for*r many.”*r
Two Blind Men Receive Sight
As*p Jesus and his disciples were leaving Jericho, a large crowd followed him.
Two blind men were sitting by the roadside, and when they heard that Jesus was going by, they shouted, “Lord, Son of David, have mercy on us!”
The*p crowd rebuked them and told them to be quiet, but they shouted all the louder, “Lord, Son of David, have mercy on us!”
Jesus*p stopped and called them. “What*r do*r you*r want*r me*r to*r do*r for*r you?”*r he asked.
“Lord,”*p they answered, “we want our sight.”
Jesus*p had compassion on them and touched their eyes. Immediately they received their sight and followed him.
